text:
¬†@misskt¬† vaccines are not a cash cow for pharmaceutical companies because they're mostly 1 time use per person. 

The actual cash cows are "supplements" because there is very little regulation around them, so there is no requirement to make studies to prove effectiveness or safety, hence less fixed costs; since that cost does not exist, the profit margin is actually way bigger than any other product and all sorts of misinformed people buy them on a regular basis.

Second place is medication for chronic diseases (e.g. hypertension, liver diseases, renal diseases) since they have to be bought on a regular basis to maintain treatment.


Vaccines are typically sold at almost no profit margin as countries typically put in place laws that forbid it and co-fund the research due to the public health aspects that countries want to keep under control. 


So, no, you are wrong. Vaccines are not a cash cow.

text:
¬†@Lila Christina Polutta¬† I sorry for your suffering and any bad experiences you might have passed through.

OTOH, you must understand that, like it or not, all treatments have risks and in the medical field it is always about risks vs benefits.

For instance, as cruel as that might sound, very old people getting hip fractures are not put under surgery due to the extreme risk of complications, even if the alternative is suffering chronic pain and a very long healing process, if it ever happens.

Regarding the components of the vaccines, please note that no vaccine or medication stays forever the same, they all are subject to continuous observation and can be changed or withdrawn from use, if issues are identified or if better alternatives are identified. So even if we assume some compound in some vaccine created some years ago was found to be problematic, it would be replaced by a safer alternative or the use would be suspended if such an issue was identified.

Also note that many of the vaccine ingredients are reused in multiple similar vaccines, so if such issue existed with one ingredient, it would likely be visible and many vaccines would be affected. So it very unlikely such a situation would persist.

To move out of the assumptions and vague claims land into the concrete, do you have any specific substance and claims regarding their alleged long term problems which you can back up by some credible sources like observational studies?

On the matter of better alternatives, it is unethical to design any kind of test trial on people that does not offer the best available treatment as a baseline and such a trial would be typically rejected by all authorities that are overseeing the medication regulations and research has been done properly, correctly and according to the law.

text: I watched this with no prior beliefs or opinions about vaccinations -- if anything, I leaned toward the pro side of the debate. During this talk, starting just after the 18-minute mark, I was initially frustrated by the interviewer's reluctance to listen to RFK Jr when he spoke about vaccines (he asked the questions, but then seemed to scoff at or dismiss the responses), but I think his resistance actually ended up highlighting his own lack of knowledge about the topic while increasing the credibility and soundness of RFK Jr's statements. RFK Jr is not anti-vaccine, he is pro-safe-testing of vaccines (by independent regulators and scientists who are not working for or paid by the company that is marketing them) before they are used. His motivation is not to be right, only to ensure that millions and millions of people, most of the them children, are not being injected with toxic substances. Prior to 1989, children got 3 vaccines; currently, they are mandated to get 72, with unknown consequences. Facebook, Google and other media platforms have shut RFK Jr down. I feel great admiration for his intelligent perspective, hard work and courage as well as deep concern about the lack of impartial safety-testing done on the vaccinations that are currently being administered. I don't know what is true here, but the world needs, at the very least, to hear what he has to say. Thank you, RFK Jr. (I would advise using the CC feature to listen to this, although be forewarned that the quality of the subtitles is quite poor.)

text:
dislecksick   First off, I agree that the world indeed is not flat and there are quite a few ‚Äúconspiracy theories‚Äù that are way out in left field.  With that out of the way, what do you consider to be relevant available literature?  In making that statement, it should typically be followed by references to support it.  And I‚Äôm not insulting, just simply asking.  Personally, I think anything one reads whether it be information from the CDC or FDA or any other source considered credible needs to be viewed objectively.  For example, that 1 out of 100 educated individual is going to read an official study to see where there might be holes.  They will check to see who benefits from the production and distribution of vaccines and how those folks were involved in the study itself.  The way I see it, any study on anything that directly involves those who may profit from it opposed to purely independent sources immediately becomes questionable.  GMO crops are a good current example.  Monsanto has had connections within the FDA for quite some time and the testing done on the effects of GMO‚Äôs was limited at best before their products that are in a very high percentage of food were approved.  But one can go read credible reports from sources such as the FDA and it will sound as though all proper steps were taken, no stone unturned.  When the reality is, they were no better than studies involving cigarettes which at one point were basically considered to be harmless and people smoked everywhere without really questioning it.  

Point being....there are a lot of Kooks out there but there is also a lot of data presented on certain topics that if you dive in a bit deeper to see who is involved, not everything adds up.  Not surprising a man who‚Äôs father and uncle were both killed under very questionable circumstances tends to question what he‚Äôs being told and what he‚Äôs reading versus what might actually be happening.  I mean, if nobody questions things, wouldn‚Äôt that make it quite simple to get away with just about anything?  Regarding Gates, when I start reading about technology to microchip humans for tracking purposes, I am going to question the motives of that technology to no end.
